Yes, all rotor-based encryption machines at the time had the vulnerability that a letter could never be encrypted to itself. This was a fundamental limitation of the technology, and was a consequence of the way in which the rotor-based encryption machines worked.

In a rotor-based machine, each letter of the plaintext is encrypted by passing it through a series of rotors that scramble the letters in a predetermined way. The resulting ciphertext is then transmitted or recorded for later decryption using the same machine and key settings.

Because of the way in which the rotors are wired and configured, it is not possible for a letter to be encrypted to itself using the same machine and key settings. This means that certain types of attacks, such as those based on known plaintext or cribs, can be more effective against rotor-based encryption machines than against other types of ciphers.

Despite this vulnerability, rotor-based encryption machines such as the Enigma machine were still considered to be highly secure and were used extensively by military and government organizations during the early to mid-20th century. It was only through the efforts of skilled codebreakers and cryptanalysts, such as those at Bletchley Park, that the vulnerabilities of these machines were ultimately exposed and exploited.
